channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Harriet Mills, Scholar Held in ‘Brainwashing Prison’ in China, Dies at 95
item.description: Ms. Mills, imprisoned as an American spy in Communist China in the 1950s, later made clear to her sister that she had been indoctrinated.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: Harriet Mills in an undated photo made available by her sister. After returning from captivity in China, she taught Chinese language and literature at Columbia, Cornell and the University of Michigan.

item.title: Fabienne Vansteenkiste, Brussels Airport Worker, Died After Staying Late
item.description: Ms. Vansteenkiste, who worked at a check-in counter, had stayed as a favor to a co-worker, and was set to leave soon when the attacks began.
item.dc:creator: NEIL COLLIER and HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.media:description: Fabienne Vansteenkiste in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Tribunal Releases Journalist Held 5 Days in a Prison for War Criminals
item.description: Florence Hartmann, from France, was held on a 2009 warrant for contempt of court, for writing about the confidential workings of tribunal judges.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Nuclear Materials Remain Vulnerable to Theft, Despite U.S.-Led Effort
item.description: As President Obama gathers leaders for his last Nuclear Security Summit, tons of materials that terrorists could use to make small nuclear devices or dirty bombs remain vulnerable to theft.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Trucks transported highly enriched uranium in Kiev, Ukraine, in March 2012, part of an American-sponsored effort to remove from the country a stockpile of fuel large enough for eight or more nuclear bombs.

item.title: Israel Changes Tack After Standoff With Brazil Over Dani Dayan
item.description: Plans to name the former settler leader as envoy to the South American nation were dropped after Brasília refused to approve the appointment.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The former settler leader Dani Dayan, who has been appointed consul general in New York, at a conference in Jerusalem on Monday on fighting a boycott against Israeli goods.

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Loses Support From Key Part of Brazilian Coalition
item.description: The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party’s leaders voted to split from the president’s party, a move that could increase the likelihood of her being impeached.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: No One Hurt as EgyptAir Flight Is Forced to Cyprus in a Hijacking From the Heart
item.description: A man claiming to wear an explosive vest forced an EgyptAir plane to land in Cyprus before he was arrested. He had issued an incoherent set of demands, and wanted to see his ex-wife.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF
item.media:description: A hostage escaping by climbing out of the cockpit of an EgyptAir plane in Cyprus, where the hijacker’s former wife lives.

item.title: World Briefing: Greece: Border Protests Intensify
item.description: Youths threw rocks at riot police officers, who withdrew from the area without making any arrests, the authorities said.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Myanmar: State Curfew Is Lifted
item.description: Myanmar’s departing government has lifted a nearly four-year curfew in Rakhine, where clashes between Rohingya Muslims and Buddhists left more than 200 people dead.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Angola: Members of Book Club Are Convicted of Plotting a Coup
item.description: A group of 17 political activists known as the Luanda Book Club received prison sentences for plotting to overthrow Angola’s government.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: El Salvador: Prison Lockdown
item.description: The government declared a state of emergency at seven prisons at the start of “extraordinary measures” it has promised to take to combat gang violence.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Fighters Laid Mines Around Palmyra’s Ancient Ruins Before Retreating, Syrians Say
item.description: Islamic State fighters were reported to have booby-trapped Palmyra’s archaeological treasures before retreating.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Children Pay ‘Highest Price’ as Yemen Falls Apart, U.N. Says
item.description: The conflict and the deteriorating humanitarian conditions in the Middle Eastern country put it at risk of becoming a failed state, Unicef reported.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Children in Sana, the capital of Yemen, in February 2015. Unicef reported that at least 934 children have been killed in the conflict, 61 percent of them in airstrikes, and that an additional 1,356 were wounded.

item.title: U.N. Panel’s Call for Transparency Highlights Limits of Oversight
item.description: A report from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon gave recommendations to the General Assembly president, who does not report to the secretary general.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Anonymous Call for Xi to Quit Rattles Party Leaders in China
item.description: A far-reaching investigation into the origin of the letter, which first appeared on the Internet, has drawn more attention than the document itself.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Police officers removing posters of President Xi Jinping of China from a house in Shanghai apparently scheduled to be demolished. An anonymous letter calling on Mr. Xi to resign appeared on the Internet this month.

item.title: Pakistan Releases Video of Indian Officer, Saying He’s a Spy
item.description: In a six-minute video, the officer, who was arrested this month, acknowledges carrying out a list of operations. India has denied that he is an intelligence operative.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: The Pakistani military spokesman Lt. Gen Asim Saleem Bajwa, left, during a news conference on Tuesday in Islamabad at which a video was shown of Kulbhushan Yadav, an Indian naval officer who is accused of being a spy.

item.title: Political Stability in the Balance as Ukraine Ousts Top Prosecutor
item.description: Viktor Shokin had been widely criticized for turning a blind eye to corrupt practices, but observers of Ukrainian politics said he had played an important role in balancing competing interests.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Viktor Shokin, who was ousted on Tuesday as prosecutor general of Ukraine.

item.title: Nic Coopman, ‘Unflappable’ Belgian Working for U.S. Company, Dies in Brussels Attack
item.description: Mr. Coopman traveled often throughout Europe and to the United States for his job, in which he specialized in automation and electrical controls.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS and ELI ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Nic Coopman in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Aline Bastin, Who Loved to See and Photograph the World, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Ms. Bastin, a press and communications manager for the Community of European Railway and Infrastructure Companies, was killed in the attack on the Brussels subway.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.media:description: Aline Bastin in a photograph on social media.

item.title: Why Airline Hijackings Became Relatively Rare
item.description: After reaching a grim apex on Sept. 11, 2001, hijackings have become less and less common, partly because of tighter security precautions.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Federal Bureau of Investigation, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of the hijacker known as D.▥B. Cooper was made from the recollections of passengers and crew members on an airplane hijacked between Portland, Ore., and Seattle in 1971.
